text: I’m Hispanic and I know this song was meant for my beautiful dark skinned sisters ❤️, but I feel a connection to this beautiful song. Growing up I was always told by my dads Family to stay out of the sun and not to get darker then what I already am because it won’t look good on me. I was told that I would stain my skin. Fast forward I’ve had my own little Queens 👑 who have a darker skin tone than Me and I have learned to appreciate more and more and as for my family that used to tell me those things, they’ve all been cut out of our lives. Now I’m learning to teach my Queens to love themselves no matter what they look like.
author: Angie V

text: I think the part with Beyonce and Kelly at the end as they stare into each other's eyes with the lyrics "'I'd never trade you for anybody else" happening at the same time is the most touching part of this video, just for the sake of their personal relationship. Beyonce considers Kelly every bit her true sister as much as Solange. The two of them have been through so much together from childhood, success/fame, navigating the entertainment industry, motherhood, and so much more. Kelly is one of Bey's ride or dies and Bey will never forget that. Also, the song and video may also be Bey's way of addressing colorism and the longtime narrative that Kelly's darker complexion held her solo career back while Bey's lighter complexion helped to fuel hers. This was Bey's public way of telling Kelly she's enough and she's beautiful the way she is.

text:
The opening shots of this hymn to the transcendental importance of Mother Afrika, and to the shattering beauty and loveliness of all daughters of Africa, is itself a mesmerising soundscape and tone-poem of whispers and harmonies.

Everything about this "tondichtung of love", and song of feminist assertiveness, and hymn of the "beauty like diamonds and pearls" of "melanin too dark to throw her shade", is stunning, and of the utmost personal and geopolitical weight.

Genius of the highest rank.

Love, andrea

text:
I wear glasses and I also have frizzy curly hair. That's why people consider me as an ugly girl. I was told by people including relatives and families that I'm really ugly or unattractive according to television actresses. When I watch Lizzo, Serena Williams, Viola Davis, Beyonce, Jennifer Hudson, Lady Gaga, Whoopi Goldberg, Mindy Kailing, Taraji.P. Henson, Amy Schumer, Sheryl Lee Ralph then I felt pretty and confidence. After listening to their speech, movies and songs I gained confidence. Right now I feel that I'm beautiful 😍❣️. Everyone is beautiful. Nobody is ugly or unattractive we are all living in a judgemental society which is a curse for our lives and also created by unrealistic beauty standards. I can't understand if people can say that Angelina, Bella they are extraordinary beautiful why can't they say that - Julia Pastrana, Serena Williams, Whoopi Goldberg, Halle Berry, Jennifer Hudson, Mindy Kailing, Venus Williams, Sarah Jessica, Lizzie, Gaboury Sidibe, Lizzo, Taraji. P. Henson, Viola Davis, Kerry Washington they are also extraordinarily beautiful 😍💐??? Black, Brown, White we are all beautiful. Not only sharp nose, tall height, big eyes, thin lips, Skiny body is beautiful but also Wide nose, short height, small eyes, fat lips, curvey body is beautiful. Therefore, we are all beautiful🌹. 
#weareallbeautiful.
#beconfident ❤.
author: A.H.M MuMu

text:
Beyonce is the best female artist nowadays. Her vocals are beyond perfection and i love so much that her late album is more African, it shows her roots and her power.  
African woman suffered so much  . The traditions of their own countries, the brutality of men, slavery in USA, segregation, the lack of    possibilities to work and be what they wanted to be. Only now the situation is changing. They could become a political figure, a well paid artist, a doctor. And the worst thing is that our DNA is almost similar, white and brown skin is only colour, but people suffered so much though history because of prejudice. It makes me so sad. The colour purple ( film) as an example of that sad and cruel life of brown women. So glad that it came to an end.

text:
This just made me burst into tears.  It has taken me such a long time being comfortable being black.  Because I grew up in a rural area literally surrounded by white people who would treat me differently because I was black.  Between people making fun of my braids, my extensions or just calling me a nig*er for walking down the street.  

It hurts a lot...  having to be on my guard whenever I'm around a group of mostly yt ppl, always waiting for someone to Crack a "joke "  about my skin or my hair....

This made me feel...beautiful....maybe not quite that.  But accepted ..

text:
‘Melanin is too dark to throw her shade'. Now that's BADASS and savage reply to anyone who tries to bring us down. 
I am an Indian girl and olive skinned (light brown maybe) whose relatives were so concerned about me being brown as a child because who will marry her!!!. The West has its own reasons but in india the only point is being a perfect marriage candidate because they want a model-like girl as a bride but not with those clothes😅. But as i am lighter shade now, they think i am a somewhat perfect candidate.
Someone like me who loves indian culture deeply. I really want this colonial colourism to go away. India is beautiful and diverse in cultures and especially north India has these stereotypes, i hope we can reclaim our culture again and get rid of these biases. 🤎

text: I am half black and half Puerto Rican and my skin is light but I've grown up around black people my whole life (I don't know my Puerto Rican side unfortunately ☹️) and I've experienced the reverse side of colorism. I was called white girl by many growing up and always wanted darker skin as a child (not anymore, I love my complexion now). I have a lot of aunts and uncles and most of my aunts are dark, I have one that's a little lighter than the rest but I have always seen just as much beauty in a darker woman as in any other woman. What bothers me is when I am with someone (black people) and they will make a comment about how dark and ugly someone is and I will literally look at the same person they are referring to and see absolute beauty. It saddens me so bad what darker women go through within our community and otherwise. I pray every brown skin woman in this planet gets the chance to hear this song 🙏 You are ALL gorgeous and don't let ANYONE tell you different.

text:
As a white girl from Europe, I can't wrap my head around the fact that someone would ever want to deny that black is beautiful — would want to degrade anyone based on any skin color, race or ethnicity. This is so wild. Makes no sense and feels like utter madness.
There are so many skin colors in the world, and that's amazing. They're so varied, and that's beautiful. From Nordic pale to dark African night, each shade has its own unique beauty, and tells its owner's story, and the story of their people. Why on earth would anyone deny any skin color the pride and the right to shine? I can't understand that. Crazy. Just crazy.
author: Lynn

text:
It’s 2023 and I have a set of twin 5 yr olds 1 darker in complexion and the other lighter.  My beautiful chocolate baby was being called ugly names at school due to her darker skin tone so I reminded her of how we’re all made beautifully in Gods image and are all a perfect reflection of Him made by His love no matter what color He bestowed upon us.  At the end of our talk I played this song and to see her face light up and to see her sing along with the words and start dancing and feeling proud of her beautiful brown skin simply brought tears to my eyes.  

THANK YOU BEYONCÉ!!!

We don’t have to teach children to be mean…we have to teach them to be KIND 😔
